# Marco Rubio’s New World Order

**From:** The New Yorker Weekly <newyorker@newsletter.newyorker.com>
**Date:** Mon, 12 Jan 2026 19:31:21 -0500 (EST)
**Source:** [View original](https://link.newyorker.com/view/5bea16dd3f92a40469736b16pw866.81fa/8fa174e7)

---

The New Yorker Weekly Newsletter

Plus: why the protests in Iran are different this time; and Minneapolis after the ICE shooting.

[

](https://link.newyorker.com/view/5bea16dd3f92a40469736b16pw866.81fa/8fa174e7)

The New Yorker&#x2019;s award-winning journalism is made possible by our subscribers. [Become one today &#xBB;](https://link.newyorker.com/click/43493982.)

In today&#x2019;s edition: Dexter Filkins reports on Marco Rubio&#x2019;s transformation from Reagan conservative to Trump enabler. Plus: why the protests in Iran are different this time; and Minneapolis after the ICE shooting. [Jump to a complete list of what&#x2019;s in this week&#x2019;s issue](https://link.newyorker.com/click/43493982.).

David Remnick

Editor, The New Yorker

Marco Rubio has developed a two-step routine in service of Donald Trump, Dexter Filkins observes in [a timely and penetrating Profile in this week&#x2019;s issue](https://link.newyorker.com/click/43493982.375094/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubmV3eW9ya2VyLmNvbS9tYWdhemluZS8yMDI2LzAxLzE5L21hcmNvLXJ1YmlvLXByb2ZpbGU_). Step one: praise the boss, effusively, as a hero. (A sample post from Rubio&#x2019;s X account: &#x201C;Thank you @POTUS for standing up for America in a way that no President has ever had the courage to do before.&#x201D;) Step two: explain that whatever unprecedented thing the President has just done&#x2014;capturing the head of state of another country in the middle of the night, [promising to take control of Greenland](https://link.newyorker.com/click/43493982.)&#x2014;is, in fact, entirely normal.

Illustration by AJ Dungo; Source photograph by Andrew Harnik / Getty

Rubio&#x2019;s dual titles of Secretary of State and national-security adviser, as Filkins points out, would make him the most powerful American diplomat since Henry Kissinger. And yet, by comparison, Rubio seems less like a foreign-policy adviser and more &#x201C;like a support staffer for the President,&#x201D; Filkins writes. &#x201C;Ultimately, he has to be a hundred per cent loyal to the President, and when the President zigs and zags Rubio has to zig and zag, too,&#x201D; one former Western diplomat who&#x2019;s worked with Rubio said. &#x201C;He&#x2019;s had to swallow a lot of shit.&#x201D; Rubio has alienated many in the foreign-policy world. As one retired ambassador told Filkins, &#x201C;Trashing our allies, gutting State and foreign aid, the tariffs&#x2014;the damage is going to take years to repair, if it can ever be repaired. I hope it ruins his career.&#x201D;

Filkins traces Rubio&#x2019;s origins, his early days in the Florida state House, his failed 2016 Presidential campaign, and, now, his present position at the side of a former rival who mocked him as &#x201C;Little Marco.&#x201D; The resulting portrait is of a man who is ideologically malleable, always ready to execute on the President&#x2019;s most draconian impulses. Last year, Rubio oversaw the gutting of U.S.A.I.D.&#x2014;just years after he lobbied the Biden Administration to increase the agency&#x2019;s budget. As one political figure in Miami put it to Filkins, &#x201C;The one constant in Marco Rubio&#x2019;s career is that he has betrayed every mentor and every principle he&#x2019;s ever had in order to claim power for himself.&#x201D;

Filkins&#x2019;s Profile of the Secretary of State is filled with remarkable observations from those who worked with Rubio in the past and who work with him now in the White House. At a moment when Trump has abandoned the America First ideology of his first term and ordered military operations in Venezuela, Iran, and Syria, and has threatened Canada, Greenland, Cuba, Colombia, and the future of the NATO alliance, Rubio is his most critical aide&#x2013;&#x2013;and a potential successor.

[Read the story](https://link.newyorker.com/click/43493982.375094/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubmV3eW9ya2VyLmNvbS9tYWdhemluZS8yMDI2LzAxLzE5L21hcmNvLXJ1YmlvLXByb2ZpbGU_)

In Case You Missed It

The Lede
An ICE Killing Puts Minneapolis on the Brink

The city where George Floyd was murdered finds itself again at the epicenter of a national crisis.

By E. Tammy Kim

Q. & A.
What Makes the Iranian Protests Different This Time

Unrest has spread across the Islamic Republic as it faces economic disaster at home and a profound weakening of its network of regional allies.

By Isaac Chotiner

The Lede
The Aggressive Ambitions of Trump&#x2019;s &#x201C;Donroe Doctrine&#x201D;

After his assault on Venezuela, the President is turning his attention to the rest of the Western Hemisphere.

By Robin Wright

The Lede
What &#x201C;The Pitt&#x201D; Taught Me About Being a Doctor

It&#x2019;s as if the show&#x2019;s creators absorbed every important conversation in health care today&#x2014;and somehow transfigured it into good television.

By Dhruv Khullar

Critic&#x2019;s Notebook
The Delicious Anticipation&#x2013;and, Yes, Release&#x2014;of &#x201C;Heated Rivalry&#x201D;

The show, a sexy romance between two closeted hockey players, began on a small Canadian streaming platform, but has become a huge, unexpected hit.

By Naomi Fry

Quote of the Week

&#x201C;What some of Trump&#x2019;s own senior officials once viewed as the delusional musings of a dilettante have now become a genuine international crisis.&#x201D;

&#x2014; Susan B. Glasser on Trump&#x2019;s Greenland obsession and threats to NATO.

Podcasts

The New Yorker Radio Hour: The historian Daniel Immerwahr says that Trump&#x2019;s embrace of imperialist adventuring is not just about business interests&#x2014;it&#x2019;s an appeal to masculinity which &#x201C;seems to sell.&#x201D; [Listen and follow &#xBB;](https://link.newyorker.com/external/43493982.)

&#x201C;Blood Relatives,&#x201D; from In the Dark: A six-part series that asks whether one of the U.K.&#x2019;s most famous murder cases ended with a wrongful conviction. [Listen and follow &#xBB;](https://link.newyorker.com/external/43493982.)
